Subdivision.Name: Basic science
Subdivision.DetailedDescription: The basic sciences of medicine are all about how nature works and about how it interacts with humans. It shows us the basics of medicine, without actually delving into the structures that we usually think of as 'human'. Still, they are some of the most high-value subjects to be studying! Good luck~

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Genetics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The DNA and RNA that makes us ... us

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Cell biology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The biology of our smallest units

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Embryology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: About who we are and where we come from

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Infectious disease
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Microbes, viruses and everything in between

Subdivision.Name: Applied science
Subdivision.DetailedDescription: The applied sciences make up the bulk of medicine. They describe how the human body is constructed and works. The structures and functions described in the applied sciences form the basis for clinical pathology and disease categories.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Anatomy
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The structures that determine how we are
DetailedCardInfo.DetailedDescription: Anatomy is the science that describes the structure of the human body. It is essential to be able to not only understand, but also to locate the the source of symptoms.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Respiratory sytem
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Rule 1 of medicine: keep air in the lung

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Digestive system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: A bunch of bullsh*it

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Circulatory system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Rule 2 of medicine: keep the heart pumping

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Integumentary system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: We're just sacks of flesh and bones

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Skeletal sytem
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Bones. Just bones, bro!

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Introduction
DetailedCardInfo.Description: What are bones?

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Muscular system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: I'll be back!

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Introduction
DetailedCardInfo.Description: What are muscles?

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Axial muscles
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Abs, bro! Chicks dig 'em

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Upper (axio)appendicular muscles
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Chest and arms, bro! Beats everything

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Lower (axio)appendicular muscles
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Never skip leg day!

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Endocrine system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: You're being hormonal right now...

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Exocrine system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Brb. Crying tears of joy rn

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Lymphatic system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The circulatory system's less famous cousin

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Nervous system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: They hate us, cause they ain't us

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Introduction
DetailedCardInfo.Description: What are nerves?

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Brain
DetailedCardInfo.Description: What makes us ... us

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Cerebrum
DetailedCardInfo.Description: When we say someone is 'cerebral', this is it

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Cerebellum
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The big thing, but small

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Brainstem
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The ultimate sine-qua-non

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Peripheral nervous system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Don't shoot the messenger!

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Somatic nervous system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: We are what we do

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Visceral nervous system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Just a gut feeling...

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Reproductive system
DetailedCardInfo.Description: All c*nts and d*ckheads

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Physiology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: What works how ... or at least how it`s supposed to work

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Psychology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Mens sana in corpore sana. Amen.

Subdivision.Name: Clinical science
Subdivision.DetailedDescription: So, then there it is: medicine. Basically, medicine is about the clinical sciences. If you master the art of diagnosis and treatment, you`re on your way to be a great doctor. It`s all about pattern recognition and creative thinking here. You think you`ve got what it takes?

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Internal medicine
DetailedCardInfo.Description: All the fleshy parts protected by our bones.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Psychiatry
DetailedCardInfo.Description: What`s inside that noggin` of yours.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Paediatrics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: About humans. But small.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Orthopaedics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Bones. Just bones, bro!

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Neurology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Everything you don`t understand.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Muscles & shit. Disability.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Cardiology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: What makes us tick. Tack. Tick. Tack.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Surgical Techniques
DetailedCardInfo.Description: How to sew a foot back on.

Subdivision.Name: Metascience
Subdivision.DetailedDescription: Here we are: we`ve considered the basics of medicine, the building blocks of the human body and everything that can go wrong with it. Now what about what we should, or shouldn`t do? Or whether we`re actually there ... like, at all? The metasciences teach us all that, and more, probably, I think ... therefore I am.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Ethics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The science of what we should and shouldn`t do

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Research methodology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: How we know what we know now, no?

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Medical law
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Limited only to the jurisdiction of the Kingdom of the Netherlands!.
